DREAMS
My brain is fagged; its erstwhile power seems gone;
I'm paying dearly for the pace which life
Has bade me keep, for days, for weeks, for months,
Until I wonder, after all is done,
If life is worth the pace which we must run.
I yield to doubt, I lose my hold, then sleep—
And dream, and in the morning am refreshed,
And grapple tasks which, but the night before,
Seemed huge, and not for mortal hands to touch.—

Class of 1924, inspired by the success of the first June Week, voted

(Signed) JOHN T. MYERS,

Treasurer.
Throughout the whole year the members of the June Week Committee have been toiling even into the early hours of morning, and as a
result the campus has been transformed into fairy lands for dancers.
Little can we realize, who did not help, the extraordinary amount of labor
which was required in preparation of this gala week. Those in charge
have done well, they have brought the undergraduate days of Class of
1924 to an end in a blaze of color and glory, and their efforts are
crowned with all the laurels of success.
With artistic and elaborate decorations completed, with the best of
music and refreshments provided, and with all the details finally arranged,
June Week is now at its height. Class Day has been and will be always
resplendent in honors. Honors of all kinds, in recognition of scholarship, leadership and athletics will be awarded.
In congratulating the departing Seniors on their honors and their
marked success with the June Week festivities, allow us to extend our
heartiest congratulations to the 0. D. K. cup winner, unquestionablly
the highest honored individual.

GODSPEED 1924
Intermingled with the predominating joy of June Week celebration
is evidenced a certain fervent touch of sadness. The Senior finds himself compelled to sever active relationship with a body of undergraduates
whom he has learned to love and with a Faculty he has learned to admire,
and perforce adds his name to the roll of Alumni. Nor are Seniors
alone in this feeling, for Juniors, Sophomores, and Freshmen share in
the unpleasant task of bidding "farewell" to the members of the Class
of 1924.
The Seniors have reached the goal for which they have been striving for four years and are about to undertake their life's work with the
long-awaited diploma. Our one desire is that, although the "four bright
years of college" are ended, the members of the Class of 1924 will continue an association with the University.
THE NEWS-LETTER, and it speaks for the undergraduate body, has
the privilege of wishing the graduating class "Godspeed."

REPORT OF PRESIDENT OF
-11105TUDENT ACTIVITIES
COUNCIL
Mr. President and Members of the
Student Activities Council:
The following is my report for
the year 1923-24, and contains an
account of the work of the Council
for the past year, a brief summary
of the conditions of the activities
represented and a brief financial
statement for each.
All of the regular monthly meetings were held, but owing to conflicts, a number of them had to be
postponed until after the first week
as prescribed. The treasurer's report for each month showed the activities always to be on a firm financial footing. Following the recommendation made by the Council
last year, a ledger was purchased
in the fall, in which the managers
of all the organizations were required to enter their detailed accounts. This has been found of
great assistance in keeping a check
on _ the progress of the activities.
These individual accounts are always open for inspection. All accounts are audited by an officer of
the university.
During the year 576 student
tickets were issued, giving a total
revenue of $5,760.00. From other
sources the activities have acquired
$8,178.57. To date there are accounts outstanding, aggregating to
approximately $4,000.00, nearly all
owed by advertisers. The interest
on the bank account has aniounted
to about $75.00.
It was decided to have only one
presentation of Varsity seals this
year, which should be on Class day
during June Week. This year, forty-five seals will be awarded. Thir-

started to become a nuisance and
was lowering the value of the Varsity Seal. Acting upon a recommendation from the honorary society, the Council was able to persuade all the activities to give up

seal as a reward for services.
Now, I wish only to give a brief
sketch of the work of each organization, pointing out the progress
they have made during the past
year.

its history as far as its business
department is concerned. It had a
larger subscription list than ever
before and has been flooded with
advertising. The editorial board has
improved its issue with a number
of cuts and several extra-sized issues.
The Hullabaloo is promising a
splendid edition, about the same
size as last year, with the addition
of several new features. The number of copies will be the same as
last year. The book is scheduled to
come out about May 25.

Third class cabins on these ships accommodate 2, 4 or 6
clean, airy and comfortable. The berths

DREAMS
My brain is fagged; its erstwhile power seems gone;
I'm paying dearly for the pace which life
Has bade me keep, for days, for weeks, for months,
Until I wonder, after all is done,
If life is worth the pace which we must run.
I yield to doubt, I lose my hold, then sleep—
And dream, and in the morning am refreshed,
And grapple tasks which, but the night before,
Seemed huge, and not for mortal hands to touch.—

Throughout the whole year the members of the June Week Committee have been toiling even into the early hours of morning, and as a
result the campus has been transformed into fairy lands for dancers.
Little can we realize, who did not help, the extraordinary amount of labor
which was required in preparation of this gala week. Those in charge
have done well, they have brought the undergraduate days of Class of
1924 to an end in a blaze of color and glory, and their efforts are
crowned with all the laurels of success.
With artistic and elaborate decorations completed, with the best of
music and refreshments provided, and with all the details finally arranged,
June Week is now at its height. Class Day has been and will be always
resplendent in honors. Honors of all kinds, in recognition of scholarship, leadership and athletics will be awarded.
In congratulating the departing Seniors on their honors and their
marked success with the June Week festivities, allow us to extend our
heartiest congratulations to the 0. D. K. cup winner, unquestionablly
the highest honored individual.

GODSPEED 1924
Intermingled with the predominating joy of June Week celebration
is evidenced a certain fervent touch of sadness. The Senior finds himself compelled to sever active relationship with a body of undergraduates
whom he has learned to love and with a Faculty he has learned to admire,
and perforce adds his name to the roll of Alumni. Nor are Seniors
alone in this feeling, for Juniors, Sophomores, and Freshmen share in
the unpleasant task of bidding "farewell" to the members of the Class
of 1924.
The Seniors have reached the goal for which they have been striving for four years and are about to undertake their life's work with the
long-awaited diploma. Our one desire is that, although the "four bright
years of college" are ended, the members of the Class of 1924 will continue an association with the University.
THE NEWS-LETTER, and it speaks for the undergraduate body, has
the privilege of wishing the graduating class "Godspeed."

Mr. President and Members of the
Student Activities Council:
The following is my report for
the year 1923-24, and contains an
account of the work of the Council
for the past year, a brief summary
of the conditions of the activities
represented and a brief financial
statement for each.
All of the regular monthly meetings were held, but owing to conflicts, a number of them had to be
postponed until after the first week
as prescribed. The treasurer's report for each month showed the activities always to be on a firm financial footing. Following the recommendation made by the Council
last year, a ledger was purchased
in the fall, in which the managers
of all the organizations were required to enter their detailed accounts. This has been found of
great assistance in keeping a check
on _ the progress of the activities.
These individual accounts are always open for inspection. All accounts are audited by an officer of
the university.
During the year 576 student
tickets were issued, giving a total
revenue of $5,760.00. From other
sources the activities have acquired
$8,178.57. To date there are accounts outstanding, aggregating to
approximately $4,000.00, nearly all
owed by advertisers. The interest
on the bank account has aniounted
to about $75.00.

presentation of Varsity seals this
year, which should be on Class day
during June Week. This year, forty-five seals will be awarded. Thir-
